awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Liquid Chromatograph Mass Spectrometer for Research and Education in the Rural Western Illinois Region
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Professor Liguo Song from Western Illinois University (WIU) and colleagues Jenq-Kuen Huang (WIU), Meshack Afitlhile (WIU), Audra Sostarecz from Monmouth College, and Caitlin Deskins from Quincy University have acquired a high-resolution quadrupole, time-of-flight, liquid chromatograph mass spectrometer (Q-TOF-LCMS). In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species embedded in complex samples. In a typical experiment, the components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized into ions and then the masses of the ions are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows the structure of molecules in complex mixtures to be studied. An instrument with a liquid chromatograph can separate mixtures of compounds before they reach the mass spectrometer. In the time-of-flight method, the mass-to-charge ratio of an ion is determined by the way of a time measurement in which ions are accelerated by an electric field of known strength. This acceleration results in an ion having the same kinetic energy as any other ion that has the same charge. The acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the University and regional area. The instrument broadens participation by involving diverse groups of students in research and research training using this modern analytical technique. It also provides training opportunities to many undergraduate students including those from underrepresented groups and will serve as a regional resource serving neighboring universities, agricultural associations and in institutions that need forensics analyses.

The proposal is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially impacts trace level analysis of drugs of abuse in hair, investigation of the self-heating and spontaneous ignition process of vegetable oils, and investigations of the structure-function of antibacterial molecules with Langmuir monolayer films. The mass spectrometer aids researchers studying metabolic engineering of secondary alcohol dehydrogenase from the bacterium  nocardia cholesterolicum NRRL 5767 via CRISP/Cas9 genome editing and those investigating the slow pH-dependent equilibrium of protease inhibitor leupeptin. The instrument is also essential for the analyses of volatile compounds such as those in breads.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
An Agilent 6545 Q-TOF LC-MS system has been acquired and utilized to accommodate the research and educational needs in the rural western Illinois region where there are only primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs). The acquisition has greatly strengthened the research infrastructure at the participating universities, including Western Illinois University (WIU), Monmouth College, Quincy University, Bradley University and Illinois College, and enabled faculty and students to access high resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) and high resolution tandem mass spectrometry (HRMS/MS) for the first time. The acquired instrument has expanded our research capabilities, enhanced our productivity, and made us more competitive to secure federal funding. Using the acquired instrument, the primarily supported B.S. Forensic Chemistry program at WIU has been receiving greater national recognition because of enhanced ability to analyze physical evidence of illicit drugs and toxicological specimens. The acquired instrument has also been providing training opportunities to many undergraduate students, including those from underrepresented groups, and serving as a regional resource to neighboring universities and agricultural associations. A website has been constructed to facilitate training sessions, research activities, summer workshops, outreach activities, and dissemination of research results.

Based on the acquired instrument, a new Forensic Mass Spectrometry course has been developed and implemented into the B.S. Forensic Chemistry program at WIU. Accompanying products of the new course include four hundred and thirty PowerPoints slides, twenty-four lecture videos, a test bank with five hundred and twenty-six questions, a lab manual consisting of one hundred and thirteen pages, ten lab experiments, and ten lab experiment videos. The new course has been taught twice so far, in spring 2020 and spring 2021, and will be taught every spring in the future. In addition, selected course materials from the new course have been incorporated into other courses in the undergraduate curricula, e.g., Biochemistry. Furthermore, selected course materials from the new course have been used in Summer Workshops for the training of faculty, M.S. graduate students, and undergraduate students in the Summer Research Programs at WIU and participating institutions. Based on the acquired instrument, quick and fun demonstrations have also been developed for outreach activities, which has been especially effective in engaging high school students with the WIU B.S. Forensic Chemistry program.

The acquired instrument has resulted in significant research results, e.g., rapid screening of forensic drugs using nitrogen direct analysis in real time (N2 DART) time of flight mass spectrometry (TOFMS), quantification of the date rape drug gamma hydroxybutyric acid (GHB) in various drinks by hydrophilic interaction liquid chromatography electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometry (HILIC-ESI/MS/MS), accurate quantification of Δ9-tetrahydrocannabinol (Δ9-THC) and Δ9-tetrahydrocannabinolic acid A (Δ9-THCA A) among twenty cannabinoids in various products of cannabis using liquid chromatography coupled with diode array detector and electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometry (LC-DAD-ESI/MS/MS), simultaneous quantification and confirmation of all acidic non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) in equine plasma for doping control in horse racing using ultra high performance liquid chromatography coupled with electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometry (UHPLC-ESI/MS/MS). The acquired instrument has aided researches in not only forensic chemistry but also bioanalytical chemistry, biochemistry, biophysical chemistry, cell biology, inorganic chemistry and organic chemistry, e.g., metabolically engineering a secondary alcohol dehydrogenase in Nocardia Cholesterolicum NRRL 5767 via CRISP/Cas9 genome editing, investigating the role of the Arabidopsis thaliana Toc159 receptor in the import of nucleus-encoded enzymes that catalyze the synthesis of jasmonic acid, exploring the enzymatically oxidative mechanisms of bioactive molecules, and expanding the chemistry of hypervalent iodine.

In the PI’s lab, the acquired instrument has become the workhorse in every research project carried out by M.S. graduate and undergraduate student researchers. So far, twenty-one M.S. graduate students, six of them are minority students, and twenty undergraduate students, sixteen of them are female students, have been using the acquired instrument in their research experiments. Many of them have already presented their results in national, regional, state and university conferences, including the American Academy of Forensic Sciences (AAFS) Annual Scientific Meeting, the ASMS (American Society for Mass Spectrometry) Conference on Mass Spectrometry & Allied Topics, the Midwest Regional Meeting (MWRM) of the American Chemical Society (ACS), the Illinois State Academy of Science Annual Meeting, the local ACS Mark Twain section meeting, the WIU Graduate Research Conference, the WIU Natural Sciences Research Symposium, and the WIU Thomas E. Helm Undergraduate Research Day. So far, ten Journal or Juried Conference Papers have been published; and eight M.S. graduate theses have been completed. It is expected that many more Journal or Juried Conference Papers will be published and many more M.S. theses will be completed in the future.

Modified by: Liguo Song
